questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for severe acne?
questions.explanation:
Acne Severity

Treatment Options

Mild Acne
  • Over-the-counter topical treatments (benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid)
  • Topical retinoids (adapalene) (Option A ruled out)

Moderate Acne
  • Topical antibiotics (clindamycin, erythromycin)
  • Oral antibiotics (doxycycline, minocycline)
  • Topical retinoids (Option A ruled out)
  • Hormonal therapy (for females)

Severe Acne
  • Oral isotretinoin (Most effective) (Option B)
  • Oral antibiotics
  • Topical retinoids
  • Hormonal therapy (for females)
  • Intralesional corticosteroids (for cystic acne)

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the distinctive finding shown in the image below, which is pathognomonic for Psoriasis?
A 40-year-old female comes with complaints of pain in her fingernail. On examination, nail folds were seen to be red and with erythema as shown in the picture. The most likely diagnosis is.
Which of the morpholine drugs listed below is used as a nail lacquer?
A young woman has presented to the OPD with facial symptoms (acne or pimple-like lesions). Which of the following options will not be effective for treating these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Type of Acne

Treatment

Comedonal acne

Topical retinoids (tretinoin, adapalene, tazarotene)

Mild inflammatory acne

Topical benzoyl peroxide, topical antibiotics (clindamycin, erythromycin)

Moderate-severe acne

Oral antibiotics (doxycycline, minocycline), combination therapy

Severe nodulocystic acne

Oral isotretinoin (vitamin A derivative)

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old male who is experiencing hair loss, based on the provided examination findings?
questions.explanation:
Non-scarring alopecia

Exclamation mark hair

Regular nail pitting

questions.text: A disorder is characterized by recurrent hair-pulling resulting in noticeable hair loss. Which of the following statements about this disorder is not accurate? [

options.label: B
options.text: The onset is typically in adolescence or early adulthood

options.label: C
options.text: Associated with feelings of pleasure or relief after hair-pulling

options.label: D
options.text: Caused by a bacterial infection of the scalp

questions.correct_answer: D. Caused by a bacterial infection of the scalp

questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for non-scarring alopecia in patients? 1. Alopecia areata 2. Telogen effluvium 3. Androgenic alopecia 4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.explanation:
Feature

Non-Scarring Alopecia

Scarring Alopecia

Pathophysiology

Hair follicles remain intact; regrowth is possible.

Follicular destruction with fibrosis; irreversible loss.

Examples

Alopecia areata (autoimmune)

Telogen effluvium (stress-related shedding)

Androgenic alopecia (hormonal, genetic)

Frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) (lichen planopilaris variant) (Option 4 ruled out)

Lupus erythematosus

Folliculitis decalvans

Clinical Findings

Smooth scalp, no scarring

Can have exclamation mark hairs (alopecia areata)

Inflammation, erythema, follicular plugging

Scalp atrophy or fibrosis

Prognosis

Usually reversible

Permanent hair loss

Treatment

Alopecia areata: Intralesional steroids, JAK inhibitors

Telogen effluvium: Treat underlying cause

Androgenic alopecia: Minoxidil, finasteride

Frontal fibrosing alopecia: Immunosuppressants, topical corticosteroids

questions.text: A lady developed a skin reaction, as shown in the image after using a hair dye. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this condition?
Where is the apocrine gland present?
questions.explanation:
Merocrine

Apocrine

Holocrine

Mechanism

By exocytosis

The apical part of the cell is pinched off.

Whole-cell is disintegrated while secretion

Examples

Eccrine sweat glands.

Salivary glands.

Globlet cells.

Apocrine sweat glands.

Mammary glands.

Sebaceous glands

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes non-scarring alopecia? 1. Alopecia areata 2. Telogen effluvium 3. Androgenic alopecia 4. Folliculitis Decalvans
questions.explanation:
Cicatricial alopecias

Non-cicatricial alopecias

Loss of hair follicle stem cells

Stem cells are not affected

Irreversible cessation of hair cycle

Damage to hair cycle can be reversed

Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia

Dermoscopy: Ostia are present. Black dots may be seen

Examples:

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia.
  • Folliculitis.
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Scleroderma

Types:

  • Patterned: Androgenetic alopecia
  • Diffuse: Effluvium
  • Patchy:
    • Alopecia areata,
    • Trichotillomania.
    • Tinea capitis,
    • Moth-eaten alopecia

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated wIth non-scarring alopecia?
questions.explanation:
Cicatricial alopecias

Non-cicatricial alopecias

Loss of hair follicle stem cells

Stem cells are not affected

Irreversible cessation of hair cycle

Damage to hair cycle can be reversed

Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia

Dermoscopy: Ostia are present. Black dots may be seen

Examples:

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia.
  • Folliculitis.
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Scleroderma

Types:

  • Patterned: Androgenetic alopecia (Option B)
  • Diffuse: Effluvium (Option D)
  • Patchy:
    • Alopecia areata (Option A)
    • Trichotillomania
    • Tinea capitis
    • Moth-eaten alopecia

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Trichoph

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - T

questions.text: An elderly female undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer is experiencing significant hair loss. What is the most likely cause of her condition?
A 10 year old child presents with hair loss. The hair loss is patchy as shown in the image below. Which off the following types of tinea is this child suffering from ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Ectoth

Condition

Description

Hair Appearance

Other Features

Ectothrix

Fungal infection with fungus growing around the hair shaft

Brittle hair that easily breaks off

Sheath of spores visible on the outside of the hair

Endothrix

Fungal infection with fungus growing inside the hair shaft

Patchy hair loss, black dots (broken-off hair shafts)

Infection confined to the hair shaft

Kerion

Severe and inflammatory form of tinea capitis

Painful, boggy, crusted plaques with pustules

Marked inflammatory response, can lead to scarring and permanent hair loss

Favus

Chronic form of tinea capitis caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii

Formation of yellow, cup-shaped crusts called scutula

Scutula can cause permanent scarring and hair loss

questions.text: 1 st line treatment for acne and comedones should be:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Topical Acne Grade Description Treatment Options Grade I Mild acne with comedones (blackheads and whiteheads)

  • Topical retinoids (e.g., tretinoin, adapalene)
  • Topical benzoyl peroxide
  • Topical salicylic acid
  • Topical antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin, erythromycin)
  • Oil-free moisturizers and non-comedogenic cosmetics
Grade II Moderate acne with papules (inflamed, red bumps)
  • Topical retinoids
  • Topical benzoyl peroxide
  • Topical antibiotics
  • Oral antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines)
Grade III Severe acne with nodules (large, painful bumps)
  • Oral isotretinoin (for severe, resistant cases)
  • Topical retinoids
  • Topical benzoyl peroxide
Grade IV Cystic acne with scarring and extensive inflammation
  • Oral isotretinoin (for severe, resistant cases)
  • Topical retinoids

questions.text: A 40-year-old female – pain in the fingernail , on examination nail fold is seen with pus , most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Paronych

questions.text: What is the common association with the condition depicted below?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Pitting

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - I

Grade Predominant lesion present  
Grade I

Mainly Comedones

Treatment : Topical Retinoids

Eg: Adapalene, Tretinoin

 
Grade II

Mainly Papules

Treatment : Topical Retinoids + Topical Clindamycin

±

Benzoyl peroxide (for pustular lesions)

 
Grade III

Mainly Pustules

Treatment: Topical retinoids

+

Topical Clindamycin

+

Benzoyl peroxide

±

Oral antibiotics like

  • Doxycycline
Grade IV
  • Nodules, Cysts, Abscess, Hence, k/a Nodulo-cystic acne
  • It is the most severe type of acne vulgaris

Treatment: Oral retinoids
